contentrichtext.text: {{about|the Greek goddess|the Indian village|Pandia, Odisha}} In [[Greek mythology]], the goddess '''Pandia''' (Πανδία) or '''Pandeia''' (Πανδεία), meaning "all brightness",<ref>Fairbanks, [http://archive.org/stream/MythologyOfGreeceAndRomespecialReferenceToItsInfluenceOnLiterature/bulgaria_fairbanks-GRE1907#page/n175/mode/2up p. 162]. Regarding the meaning of "Pandia", Kerenyi, p. 197, says: '"the entirely shining" or the "entirely bright"— doubtless the brightness of nights of full moon.'</ref> was a daughter of [[Zeus]] and the [[List of lunar deities|moon-goddess]] [[Selene]].<ref>''Hymn to Selene'' (32) [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0138%3Ahymn%3D32 15–16]; Allen, [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0029%3Atext%3Dcomm%3Apoem%3D32 [15<nowiki>]</nowiki> "ΠανδείηΝ"], says that Pandia was "elsewhere unknown as a daughter of Selene", but see [[Hyginus]], ''[[Fabulae]]'' [http://www.theoi.com/Text/HyginusFabulae1.html Preface], [[Philodemus]], ''De pietate'' P.Herc. 243 Fragment 6 (Obbink, [http://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=D4tDMNaqKfIC&oi=fnd&pg=PA353 p. 353]).</ref> From the ''[[Homeric Hymn]] to Selene'', we have: "Once the Son of Cronos [Zeus] was joined with her [Selene] in love; and she conceived and bare a daughter Pandia, exceeding lovely amongst the deathless gods."<ref> ''Hymn to Selene'' (32) [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0138%3Ahymn%3D32 15–16].</ref> An Athenian tradition made Pandia the wife of [[Antiochus (mythology)|Antiochus]], the eponymous hero of [[Antiochis]], one of the ten Athenian tribes ([[phyle|phylai]]).<ref>See West, p. 19, which describes Pandia as an "obscure figure".</ref> Pandia may have personified the full moon,<ref>Cox, [http://books.google.com/books?id=qdzikAFo7AYC&pg=PA138 p. 138]; Casford [http://books.google.com/books?id=YQVdvH_z74oC&pg=PA174 p. 174].</ref> and an Athenian festival, called the Pandia, probably celebrated on the full-moon, may have been dedicated to her.<ref>Robertson, [http://books.google.com/books?id=AMTNIZ_LQjoC&pg=PA75 p. 75]; Willets, pp. [http://books.google.com/books?id=wz0qAAAAYAAJ&q=Pandia+Selene&dq=Pandia+Selene&hl=en&sa=X&ei=amu1Ua6yDsGmPazngLAP&redir_esc=y 178–179]; Smith, [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text;jsessionid=BDFA02D9C2623BF90A2B1EC34D743408?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0063%3Aalphabetic+letter%3DP%3Aentry+group%3D1%3Aentry%3Dpandia-cn "Pandia"].</ref> ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== * Allen, Thomas W., E.
